ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I improved my french, both speaking and writing, a lot.
I greatly improved my speaking skills in particular, and also solidified many grammatical concepts.
The class pushed my advanced knowledge of French to another level by making me apply my grammar and reading abilities to actually converse and analyze French texts and grammar rules.
This course had a remarkable impact on my grammar, vocabulary, and oral fluency skills. I learned more in one semester in this course than I did in all of high school French.
i improved my french and learned much more about French culture and how France was in the 17th and 19th century!

I learned a lot about French culture and literature. Although the vocabulary is not necessarily what French speakers use day-to-day, I still learned a lot in terms of speaking and listening -- part of that is gaining confidence as well, which Madame Schneider is very good at cultivating in her students.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: interesting material, a nice mix of speaking and writing
Weakness: it sometimes feels like there is a lot of material to cover, and we do not have enough time to cover everything in class. So lots of self studying.

I really enjoyed many of the readings/films selected for this course. The professor was very kind in encouraging participation, and her assessments were all very fair. The weekly workload is very high, as each homework assignment has multiple parts, and there are many major assessments. However, I felt these helped me maintain a high level of engagement, so I appreciated them.

The strengths of the course is the material. The books and movies are very enjoyable and are engaging. The weakness of the course is the difficulty of it. I started off taking French at Yale, and the jump from L4 to L5 is just too difficult. The experience of my other classmates in comparison to me made it very hard to enjoy and learn at my pace.
The course should be built around a theme. There was no theme to the course, so the readings and media felt disconnected, and I wasnt sure why we were reading or watching those materials.

The balance of reading assignments and grammar assignments made a nice compromise between the technical and cultural aspects of the French language. I thought the course was very well-organized, and the progression of texts went in a logical order. The end, however, did feel a little rushed; I would have liked a little more time to discuss our final text that we read. Other than that, perfect class!
the professor is really good and the books that you'll read are amazing and super engaging!

Strengths: engagement with various kinds of media, great professors!

Weaknesses: may not be the most useful for everyday living/conversation in French

Improvements: incorporating a few more contemporary / casual french conversation opportunities!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The zoom meetings worked well for me.
This course transitioned well to a virtual experience, since our class was small enough for Zoom participation to work well.
The in person lectures were very helpful and kept you accountable. We could have spent more time in breakout rooms with the teacher hopping in and out to work on speaking one on one.

Early on, we established discussion norms (keep muted until prof. calls on you, raise hands, try to limit your speaking time so as not to monopolize the conversation), and sticking to these norms really made it feel as close to an in-person class as possible. Our professor was also very responsive over email, which made all the difference when it came to asking questions about the content or the logistics of an assignment.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes.
I would recommend this course to another student if they are willing to keep up with the work. It was not overly difficult in terms of French level, and many of the readings are interesting.
If you have a background in French, then yes. If you dont and started taking French just at Yale, it is very hard to keep up.

Yes, definitely! An excellent entry course to upper-level French. I would recommend to anyone who took AP French or some equivalent in high school and is looking to gain ease, fluency, and more advanced understanding of grammar.
absolutely!
Yes! I would.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: No
N/a
